Are you talking about the boosters?  They're important in assisting spacecrafts escape the gravitational pull of the Earth during the first two minutes or so of launch.  Once the boosters are out of fuel, they are detached from the main body of the spacecraft because their presence would just add additional unwanted weight.  Many of them land in the ocean, which is recollected and their materials recycled.  But for more recent spacecraft such as the Falcon 9, the boosters would land on a platform so that it could be preserved for even more recycling purposes.  Now, there's a reason the camera goes out.  Because the platform where the booster lands is far out at sea, it needs to signal a satellite in order to get the livestream broadcasted.  The signal needs to be directional in order for it to be strong enough.  As the booster gets close to the platform, it shakes the platform due to the engine thrust, which disrupts the signal traveling to the satellite, ultimately cutting out the feed.  That's why we don't see the landing specifically, but more so before and after it happens when the platform stabilizes.
